We need to show $$\begin{aligned}
\binom{n}{k} + \binom{n}{k-1} & = & \binom{n+1}{k}\end{aligned}$$ Let us
begin by writing the left-hand side as
$$\frac{n!}{k!(n-k)!} + \frac{n!}{(k-1)!(n-(k-1))!}$$ Getting a common
denominator and simplifying, we have $$\begin{aligned}
\frac{n!}{k!(n-k)!} + \frac{n!}{(k-1)!(n-k+1)!} & = & \frac{(n-k+1)n!}{(n-k+1)k!(n-k)!}+\frac{kn!}{k(k-1)!(n-k+1)!} \\ 
& = & \frac{(n-k+1)n!+kn!}{k!(n-k+1)!} \\
& = & \frac{(n+1)n!}{k!((n+1)-k)!} \\
& = & \frac{(n+1)!}{k!((n+1)-k)!} \\
& = & \binom{n+1}{k}\end{aligned}$$
